body:
why do you need _identity_with_attr_like_rhs for backward inference? You can check if oshape is set in InferShape.

c = a + b
c.infershape(a=(10,))

So here is the case.  The shape infer comes with an order of forward then backward
- In the testcase I showed, in the forward case of `wt = w + wshift`, we know wshift is `(1,)`.
  - The legacy rule will directly assign w.shape to (1, ) , since it is forward pass and the shape of output is not yet known.
  - This prevents future inference to correct the fact that w should not be (1,)

That is why for broadcast binary op such shape inference rule is over optimistic. The current change relax the rule, to not set the shape unless it is known to be correct for 100%.

This prevent shape inference for your case, when shape of b is not given, but can be amended by either use ewise_plus instead, or add an identity_with_attr_like constraint.

I worked for me. make sure that you are using the one defined in mxnet/python/mxnet/optimizer.py

you just need to sync mxnet/python/mxnet/optimizer.py on all nodes,

such as

cat hosts | xargs -I{} scp ~/mxnet/python/mxnet/optimizer.py {}:~/
mxnet/python/mxnet/optimizer.py

@piiswrong

`wt = mx._symbol_internal._identity_with_attr_like_rhs(wt, w)` this looks like a hack.
If we want to support backward inference it should be supported in operator's infershape

so if c = a+b and you have c & a you can infer b. You can infer a & b if you only have c

there are certain time such that the hint information is needed. This is an demonstration how such info could be useful. Given shape of a and c, shape of b is not deterministic. we cannot distinguish between a broadcast dimension versus normal dimension 

for example, both (3,3) + (1,3) and (3,3)+（3，3) give the same c

The first issue is a generic issue with using cuda with docker. I think you can find solutions online

The second is a bug with cuda 7.5 where it has restrictions on the size of random array you can create. You can work around it by using np.random instead of mx.random in mx.init

the solution is as follows:
(1)install 20160531_win10_x64_gpu. execute setupenv.cmd and python setup.py install.
(2)overwrite the files with new release vesion in https://github.com/yajiedesign/mxnet/releases
(3)overwrite the cudnn files with cudnn V4
